This legal framework reformed the French legal system by consolidating various laws into a coherent code that emphasized principles such as equality before the law, secularism, and the protection of property rights. He established a merit-based system for civil service appointments, which reduced corruption and inefficiency. He believed in the importance of familial ties and often sought to elevate his relatives to positions of power, which he viewed as a means to consolidate his rule and create a loyal network of support. For instance, he appointed his brothers to thrones across Europe—Joseph as King of Spain, Louis as King of Holland, and Jérôme as King of Westphalia. These appointments were not merely acts of nepotism; they were strategic moves aimed at ensuring that his family members would govern in alignment with his policies and maintain stability in the regions under his influence.
